channel.title: Disappearances
channel.description: In 2020, after years spent searching for answers, Sarah Turney used social media to help bring justice to her sister Alissa’s nearly two decades-long disappearance. Now she’s teaming up with Parcast to explore the many reasons people disappear and the impact their absences can have on those left behind. Disappearances is a Spotify Original from Parcast. Catch a new episode every Thursday, free on Spotify.

item.title: Richey Edwards
item.description: In 1995, the 27-year-old guitarist and songwriter for the Manic Street Preachers vanishes just before a scheduled press tour. Six months later, a lead investigator believes he likely died by suicide. Those closest to him aren’t so sure. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Jim Thompson
item.description: He was a spy, then a mogul, and now — a mystery. Jim Thompson vanished in 1967 after hiking into the Malaysian jungle, leaving everyone to wonder: Had his past come back to haunt him?  Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Eloise von Wagner Bosquet
item.description: In the early 1930s, a woman claiming to be a French baroness arrives on a tiny island in the Galapagos. But by 1935, Eloise von Wagner Bosquet and three of the island’s other residents are dead or gone under mysterious circumstances. Only one woman is left to account for the disappearances. Can her story be trusted? Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Art & Margaret Williams
item.description: In 1970s Canada, Art Williams grows a drug empire by always staying one step ahead of the authorities. Then he disappears. Did he stage a plane crash to fake his death, and take his ex-wife Margaret with him? Or was she left behind, and caught in the crosshairs of his dangerous associates? Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Kathleen Durst
item.description: When Kathie Durst vanishes in January 1982, her friends immediately suspect her millionaire husband, Robert Durst. But Robert evades police scrutiny, and Kathie’s case goes cold. It takes a false police tip, an HBO documentary, and nearly four decades to piece together what happened to the 29 year old. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Helen Brach
item.description: A wealthy widow known as Chicago’s “Candy Lady” goes missing in the late 1970s — potentially in a scheme devised by the cruelest players of the city’s horse mafia. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Charles Lindbergh, Jr.
item.description: The infant son of a world-famous aviator was kidnapped and held for ransom in 1932. The case makes headlines almost immediately, but months pass before the Lindberghs discover what happened to their boy. When they do, a law is introduced that impacts kidnapping cases for decades afterward — and not always for the better. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: An Interview with Julie Murray
item.description: Following up from last week’s episode, Sarah welcomes Julie Murray onto the podcast for a conversation about her sister Maura – who she was before she disappeared, what their family has been through over the last two decades, and how plausible the most popular theories really are. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Maura Murray
item.description: Eighteen years ago, 21-year-old Maura Murray crashed her car into a snowbank off a two-lane highway in New Hampshire. It takes just minutes from when she was last seen for her to disappear completely. But why was she on Route 112 at all that night?  Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Ray Gricar
item.description: A respected DA on the brink of retirement goes missing in early April 2005. Police find his car, then his laptop, then his laptop’s hard drive, all months apart. But never a body. Was there foul play? Or did Ray Gricar want to disappear?  Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Sean Flynn & Dana Stone
item.description: In the spring of 1970, two American photojournalists go missing in the middle of a warzone. Despite multiple efforts to uncover their fate, including a failed rescue mission and a psychic reading, their whereabouts remain a mystery. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Henry Baltimore Jr.
item.description: It was almost 50 years ago when Michigan State junior Henry Baltimore was robbed at gunpoint at his apartment by an acquaintance. Weeks later, just before Henry was going to testify at the trial, he disappeared. So why, despite having an obvious suspect, do the East Lansing Police Department never seem to mount a real investigation? Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Bas Jan Ader
item.description: On a summer day in 1975, conceptual artist Bas Jan Ader steps onto a sailboat and embarks on a trans-Atlantic voyage. He never reaches his intended destination. But did he suffer a maritime tragedy — or stage another art installation? Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Stacy Ann Peterson
item.description: In Chicago 2007, the 23-year-old wife of a police officer goes missing. Her family immediately suspects foul play by her husband, Drew Peterson. But Drew is never convicted of a crime — at least, not in Stacy’s case. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Peter Winston
item.description: In the late 1970s, a famous American chess prodigy disappeared during a record-breaking blizzard in New York City. Today we go into the mind and the mystery of Peter Winston. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Jean Spangler
item.description: When a single mother vanishes after a night out in L.A., the media runs wild with speculation, overshadowing the tragedy of her story with rumors and hearsay. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Aubrey Dameron and Anthonette Cayedito
item.description: Indigenous women are murdered at a rate ten times higher than any other demographic, but the crimes against them are often ignored. Here are two heartbreaking cold cases that shed some insight into a crisis that’s lasted generations, and help explain why justice has been so (maddeningly) elusive.  Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: The Martin Family
item.description: It was a Sunday afternoon in 1958 when Ken and Barbara Martin took a drive with their three daughters and never returned home. The facts point to a tragic accident. But they also point to the possibility of homicide. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Megumi Yokota
item.description: Megumi was a 13-year-old Japanese school kid when she disappeared — apparently, without a trace. But decades later, the leads finally started to roll in. They set the Yokota family on a path that intersected with the massive intricacies of nuclear politics and international espionage. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Henry Hudson
item.description: Henry Hudson was a skilled explorer when he set out on his final voyage — but he never came home. Unfortunately, British authorities at the time didn't deem him worth an urgent search party. He'd have to wait centuries for a dedicated investigation. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Jodi Huisentruit
item.description: In 1995, everyone in Mason City, Iowa knew Jodi Huisentruit: She was their local news anchor. When she went missing, it shocked the entire town, and made national newscasts. How can you disappear when everyone knows your face? Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Richard John Bingham, Earl of Lucan
item.description: The Earl of Lucan had a glamorous life in the 1970s, but his family's facade of wealth and power came crashing down when their nanny was found murdered in their basement. Lady Lucan claimed her husband was the killer, and as the investigation took off, Lord Lucan himself disappeared into the English countryside. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Glen and Bessie Hyde
item.description: It’s a story that’s mystified people for almost a hundred years: In 1928, two daring newlyweds set out for adventure on the Colorado River… and never returned. And while the case might seem clear-cut, the legacy of Glen and Bessie Hyde — and the rumors surrounding them — are as unruly and treacherous as the rapids they ran. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Richard Cox
item.description: When a West Point cadet goes missing in 1950, the FBI and Army scour the country for him — but he’s never found. Seven years later, Richard Cox is officially declared dead. But if the theories about him are right, his story has a completely unexpected, possibly even heroic, ending. And it starts with a mysterious visitor.  Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: The Lyon Sisters
item.description: On March 25th, 1975, Sheila and Kate Lyon made the half-mile walk to the Wheaton Plaza Mall and never returned. Their disappearance stumped authorities for decades until 2013, when a tiny clue — hidden in an old witness testimony — blew the case wide open. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Harold Holt
item.description: After a deeply controversial year in office, Australia’s Prime Minister Harold Holt is on vacation in Portsea when he goes for an ocean swim… and never returns. Officially, Holt drowned. But with conspiracy theories swirling, the case never truly feels closed. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Walter Collins
item.description: On March 10th 1928, 9-year-old Walter Collins went out to see a movie and was never seen again. The police turned up compelling evidence that he'd been murdered. But Walter's mother, Christine Collins, never gave up hope — even in the face of gaslighting and an imposter. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Clarence & John Anglin, Frank Morris
item.description: June 11, 1962 marked a new day in the legacy of America’s most inescapable prison when three inmates did the impossible. Frank Morris and the Anglin brothers plotted and chiseled their way to freedom, escaping Alcatraz… never to be seen or heard from again. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Ettore Majorana
item.description: A brilliant physicist vanished from Italy in 1938, leaving only a series of cryptic letters behind. In the years-long search for Ettore Majorana, one thing became clear: If he was alive, he didn’t want to be found. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Phoenix Coldon
item.description: In December 2011, Phoenix Coldon's parents watched their daughter back out of the driveway of their home in Spanish Lake, Missouri. She doesn't say goodbye or mention a destination, but it's the last time they ever see her. Three hours later, her car is found abandoned in another state.  Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Everett Ruess
item.description: A young artist-explorer goes missing in the American Southwest in the 1930s — leaving no trace behind except two burros and a carved clue. The investigation into his disappearance spans decades, spawning theories from murder to amnesia. Through it all, one question persists above the rest: Who was Everett Ruess, really? Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Michael Rockefeller
item.description: Officially, 23-year-old Michael Rockefeller drowned off the coast of New Guinea in 1961 after his catamaran capsized. But when a Dutch missionary living with a local tribe starts hearing disturbing rumors, Michael’s disappearance gets a lot more unsettling. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Etan Patz
item.description: In May 1979, after weeks of him asking, Julie and Stan Patz finally allowed their 6-year-old son, Etan, to walk to the bus stop alone. The result was every parent’s worst nightmare: In the span of ten minutes, along just two NYC blocks, Etan Patz disappeared and was never seen again.  Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices

item.title: Introducing: Disappearances with Sarah Turney
item.description: You’ve seen the headlines: People here one day and gone the next. But no one just vanishes into thin air. The answers are out there… waiting to be found. Every Thursday, join host Sarah Turney for an exploration into history’s most gripping missing persons cases. From prison breaks and child abductions to second chances and even murder, journey through the many reasons people disappear. Disappearances is a Spotify Original from Parcast. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit podcastchoices.com/adchoices
